Questions: According to the Standard Treatment Guidelines and Essential Medicines List for South Africa Primary Healthcare Level 2020 Edition what is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated non-severe malaria at the PHC level?
Comment: The guideline states that artemether/lumefantrine is the recommended first-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria, to be taken with fat-containing food for adequate absorption[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for impetigo in a patient with no known drug allergies?
Comment: Topical mupirocin is recommended for limited impetigo[cite: 5].

Questions: Which of the following is the standard prophylaxis for an HIV-exposed infant?
Comment: The guidelines state that cotrimoxazole prophylaxis for HIV-exposed infants should be initiated from 6 weeks of age[cite: 15].

Questions: According to the guidelines which of the following is a risk factor for severe COVID-19 disease?
Comment: The guidelines identify the elderly as being at high risk for severe COVID-19 disease[cite: 7].

Questions: What is the correct treatment for an acute gout attack?
Comment: The guidelines recommend colchicine as the treatment for acute gout[cite: 14].

Questions: A patient presents with acute, uncomplicated cystitis. Which of the following is a recommended treatment?
Comment: Nitrofurantoin is a recommended treatment for acute, uncomplicated cystitis[cite: 13].

Questions: What is the recommended first-line treatment for scabies?
Comment: Benzyl benzoate 25% lotion is recommended as the first-line treatment for scabies[cite: 8].

Questions: Which of the following is a sign of severe malaria?
Comment: The guideline lists jaundice as a clinical feature of severe malaria[cite: 6].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is a key instruction for a patient on chronic therapy?
C: Inform other healthcare providers about all conditions and medicines
D: Adjust doses as needed without consulting a doctor
Comment: The guideline states that every patient on chronic therapy must inform other healthcare providers about any other condition/disease and its management when seeking medical attention for other complaints[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended first-line oral therapy for a child with tinea capitis?
Comment: Oral griseofulvin is the recommended first-line treatment for tinea capitis in children[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the first-line treatment for a patient with an acute dental abscess at a PHC level?
Comment: The guidelines recommend referral for drainage and antibiotics as the first line of management for a dental abscess[cite: 1].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for herpes simplex infections of the mouth and lips?
Comment: The guideline suggests oral aciclovir for herpes simplex infections of the mouth and lips[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with an uncomplicated urinary tract infection?
Comment: Nitrofurantoin is a recommended first-line agent for uncomplicated urinary tract infection in adults[cite: 13].

Questions: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for moderate persistent diarrhoea in a child?
Comment: The guideline recommends zinc sulphate as an adjunct to ORS for persistent diarrhoea in children[cite: 2].

Questions: Which of the following is a key component in the management of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) at the PHC level?
Comment: The guideline states that ACE-inhibitors are used in the management of Chronic Kidney Disease[cite: 4].

Questions: Which of the following is the correct management for uncomplicated gingivitis?
Comment: Uncomplicated gingivitis is managed with chlorhexidine mouthwash[cite: 1].

Questions: What is the recommended first-line treatment for chronic anal fissure?
Comment: Bulk-forming laxatives are recommended as the first-line treatment for chronic anal fissure[cite: 2].

Questions: Which medicine is recommended for the treatment of uncomplicated bacillary dysentery?
Comment: The guideline recommends azithromycin as a treatment for bacillary dysentery[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with taenia (tapeworm) infestation?
Comment: The guideline recommends praziquantel for the treatment of tapeworm infestation[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the primary intervention for a patient with acute diarrhoea without blood?
Comment: The primary intervention for acute diarrhoea is oral rehydration solution (ORS)[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for oral candidiasis (thrush)?
Comment: Nystatin oral suspension is the recommended treatment for oral thrush[cite: 1].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is the most common cause of treatment failure in malaria?
C: Taking the medicine at the wrong time
Comment: The guideline states that vomiting oral treatment is one of the commonest reasons for treatment failure in malaria[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a child with uncomplicated Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)?
Comment: Uncomplicated SAM is managed on an outpatient basis with ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF)[cite: 3].

Questions: What is the first-line antihypertensive medication recommended for a patient with hypertension and diabetes mellitus?
Comment: ACE-inhibitors are the first-line therapy for hypertension in adults with diabetes[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with post-herpes zoster neuropathy?
Comment: The guideline states that amitriptyline is recommended for post-herpes zoster neuropathy[cite: 9].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a first-line treatment for hypertension in adults?
Comment: The guideline states that beta-blockers are NOT a first-line treatment for hypertension, unless there are co-morbidities[cite: 4].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is a key management step for a patient with acute myocardial infarction (AMI)/ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) at the PHC level?
Comment: The guidelines recommend immediate referral of a patient with an AMI/STEMI[cite: 4].

Questions: Which of the following is recommended for the prevention of rheumatic fever?
Comment: Benzathine benzylpenicillin is recommended for the prevention of rheumatic fever[cite: 9].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a chronic leg ulcer caused by cellulitis?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral cefalexin as a treatment for chronic lower leg ulcers[cite: 5].

Questions: Which is a recommended treatment for mild non-specific headache?
Comment: Paracetamol is a recommended treatment for mild, non-specific headache[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the first-line treatment for moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) in children?
Comment: The guidelines state that corn-soya blend (CSB++) is the recommended treatment for moderate acute malnutrition (MAM)[cite: 3].

Questions: What is the recommended management for an uncomplicated case of ringworm?
Comment: The guideline recommends topical clotrimazole for uncomplicated ringworm (tinea corporis)[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the initial management for a patient with a boil or abscess?
Comment: The guideline states that incision and drainage is the initial management for a boil or abscess[cite: 5].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is a common treatment for atopic eczema?
Comment: Topical corticosteroids are a common treatment for atopic eczema[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with urticaria?
Comment: Oral antihistamine is the recommended treatment for urticaria[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected ectopic pregnancy at a PHC level?
Comment: The guideline states that all patients with a suspected ectopic pregnancy must be referred for a surgical assessment[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the initial management for a patient with incomplete miscarriage in the first trimester?
Comment: The guideline recommends misoprostol as the initial management for incomplete miscarriage in the first trimester[cite: 6].

Questions: Which is a recommended antenatal supplement for all pregnant women?
Comment: The guideline states that folic acid and iron supplements are recommended for all pregnant women[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the management of a patient with mild to moderate gestational hypertension?
Comment: The guidelines recommend bed rest and observation for mild to moderate gestational hypertension[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with eclampsia?
Comment: The guidelines recommend immediate delivery and magnesium sulphate for eclampsia[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for syphilis in pregnancy?
Comment: The guideline recommends benzathine benzylpenicillin as the treatment for syphilis in pregnancy[cite: 6].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for preterm labour?
D: Being of a higher socio-economic status
Comment: The guidelines state that urinary tract infection is a risk factor for preterm labour, not socio-economic status[cite: 6].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is the recommended management for preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM)?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral antibiotics and betamethasone for preterm prelabour rupture of membranes[cite: 6].

Questions: When should neonatal resuscitation be initiated?
A: Immediately after birth if the baby is not breathing
D: Only if the Apgar score is low
Comment: The guideline states that neonatal resuscitation should be initiated immediately after birth if the baby is not breathing[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended management for postpartum haemorrhage (PPH)?
Comment: Parenteral oxytocin is the recommended management for postpartum haemorrhage[cite: 6].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for chronic pelvic pain?
Comment: The guideline recommends NSAIDs as a treatment for chronic pelvic pain[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with chronic kidney disease and a GFR < 30ml/min?
Comment: The guidelines recommend referral to a nephrologist for patients with CKD and a GFR < 30ml/min[cite: 8].

Questions: Which of the following is a key management step for a patient with acute kidney injury at the PHC level?
Comment: The guidelines recommend immediate referral for patients with acute kidney injury[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for symptomatic Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)?
Comment: Tamsulosin is the recommended treatment for symptomatic Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the first-line treatment for a patient with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus?
Comment: Insulin is the recommended first-line treatment for Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended initial management for a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)?
Comment: IV fluids are the recommended initial management for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)[cite: 8].

Questions: Which of the following is a key management step for a patient with diabetic foot ulcers?
Comment: The guideline states that patients with diabetic foot ulcers should be referred to a specialist[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for adult hypothyroidism?
Comment: The guideline recommends levothyroxine as the treatment for adult hypothyroidism[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a confirmed case of measles?
Comment: The guideline states that symptomatic and supportive care is the recommended management for a patient with a confirmed case of measles[cite: 10].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for non-severe/uncomplicated malaria in a child weighing >5-15kg?
Comment: For a child weighing >5-15kg, the recommended dose of artemether/lumefantrine is 1 tablet[cite: 6].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a complication of malaria?
Comment: Hypertension is not listed as a complication of malaria, whereas hypoglycaemia, severe anaemia and jaundice are[cite: 6].

Questions: What is the recommended prophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis in close contacts?
Comment: The guideline recommends rifampicin as prophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with suspected viral haemorrhagic fever (VHF)?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral of a patient with suspected viral haemorrhagic fever[cite: 10].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with HIV and oral candidiasis?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral fluconazole as the treatment for oral candidiasis in a patient with HIV[cite: 11].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with HIV and chronic herpes simplex ulcers?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral aciclovir for chronic herpes simplex ulcers in a patient with HIV[cite: 11].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is the recommended management for a patient with HIV and cryptococcosis?
Comment: The guideline states that a patient with HIV and cryptococcosis should be immediately referred[cite: 11].

Questions: What is the recommended prophylaxis for HIV-exposed infants?
Comment: The guidelines recommend nevirapine as prophylaxis for HIV-exposed infants[cite: 11].

Questions: Which of the following is a side effect of ART in a patient with HIV?
Comment: The guideline lists lactic acidosis as a side effect of ART[cite: 11].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with vaginal discharge syndrome (VDS)?
Comment: The guideline states that the treatment for vaginal discharge syndrome is metronidazole and azithromycin[cite: 12].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for male urethritis syndrome (MUS)?
Comment: The guideline recommends ceftriaxone and azithromycin for male urethritis syndrome[cite: 12].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for genital ulcer syndrome (GUS)?
Comment: The guideline states that the treatment for genital ulcer syndrome is benzathine benzylpenicillin and oral doxycycline[cite: 12].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is the correct treatment for genital warts?
Comment: The guideline states that topical podophyllin is the recommended treatment for genital warts[cite: 12].

Questions: At what age is the first dose of the BCG vaccine given?
Comment: The guidelines state that the BCG vaccine is administered at birth[cite: 13].

Questions: At what age is the measles vaccine given?
Comment: The measles vaccine is administered at 9 months[cite: 13].

Questions: What is the correct storage temperature for vaccines?
Comment: The guideline states that vaccines must be stored in a cold chain at 2-8?¯C[cite: 13].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an acute arthritis attack caused by Gout?
Comment: The guideline states that colchicine is the recommended treatment for acute gout[cite: 14].

Questions: What is the recommended long-term treatment for chronic gout?
Comment: The guideline states that allopurinol is the recommended long-term treatment for chronic gout[cite: 14].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for osteoarthrosis?
Comment: The guideline recommends NSAIDs for the treatment of osteoarthrosis[cite: 14].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with an acute stroke?
Comment: The guideline states that all patients with an acute stroke should be referred immediately[cite: 15].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended initial treatment for a patient in status epilepticus?
Comment: The guideline recommends intramuscular midazolam as the initial treatment for status epilepticus[cite: 18].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a child with febrile convulsions?
Comment: The guideline recommends an antipyretic for the fever and referral for the febrile convulsions in children[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with acute meningitis?
Comment: The guideline states that a patient with acute meningitis should receive IV antibiotics and be referred immediately[cite: 15].

Questions: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for a patient with acute psychosis?
Comment: The guideline recommends haloperidol for the treatment of acute psychosis[cite: 16].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with an overdose of an antidepressant?
Comment: The guideline recommends activated charcoal for the treatment of an overdose of an antidepressant[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with chronic psychosis (schizophrenia)?
Comment: The guideline recommends long-term use of oral antipsychotic medication for chronic psychosis[cite: 16].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with atopic eczema who has a superimposed bacterial infection?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral cefalexin for atopic eczema with a superimposed bacterial infection[cite: 5].

Questions: According to the guidelines what is the recommended treatment for acute bacterial pneumonia in a child aged 3 years?
Comment: The guidelines recommend amoxicillin for the treatment of acute bacterial pneumonia in children aged 3 years[cite: 17].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a confirmed diagnosis of Bell's Palsy?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral corticosteroids for Bell's Palsy[cite: 15].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for a patient with scabies?
Comment: The guideline recommends benzyl benzoate 25% lotion as a treatment for scabies[cite: 8].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with chronic hypertension who has developed a cough on an ACE-inhibitor?
C: Switch to an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (ARB)
Comment: The guideline states that if a patient on an ACE-inhibitor develops a cough, they should be switched to an ARB[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a hypertensive emergency?
Comment: The guideline states that a patient with a hypertensive emergency should be referred immediately[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with stable angina?
Comment: The guideline recommends sublingual nitroglycerin as the treatment for an adult with stable angina[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with an unstable angina?
Comment: The guideline recommends aspirin as a treatment for unstable angina[cite: 4].

Questions: Which of the following is the correct management for a patient with cardiac arrest?
Comment: The guideline states that the correct management for cardiac arrest is cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR)[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with mild congestive cardiac failure?
Comment: The guideline recommends ACE-inhibitor and diuretic as the treatment for mild congestive cardiac failure[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for acute pulmonary oedema?
Comment: The guideline recommends IV furosemide for the treatment of acute pulmonary oedema[cite: 4].

Questions: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for a child with rheumatic fever?
Comment: The guideline recommends parenteral benzathine benzylpenicillin as the treatment for a child with rheumatic fever[cite: 4].

Questions: Which is a recommended treatment for dental caries?
Comment: Topical fluoride varnish is a recommended treatment for dental caries[cite: 1].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with chronic diarrhoea?
Comment: The guideline states that chronic diarrhoea requires investigation and referral to determine the underlying cause[cite: 2].

Questions: Which of the following is a key management step for a patient with complicated severe acute malnutrition (SAM)?
Comment: The guideline states that complicated SAM requires inpatient care, starting with F75[cite: 3].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with type 2 diabetes and hypertension?
Comment: The guideline recommends an ACE-inhibitor for a patient with type 2 diabetes and hypertension[cite: 9].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with type 2 diabetes and no comorbidities?
Comment: The guideline recommends metformin as the first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes in adults with no comorbidities[cite: 9].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a viral haemorrhagic fever?
Comment: The guideline states that the management for a viral haemorrhagic fever is supportive care[cite: 10].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with candidiasis of the skin?
Comment: The guideline recommends topical antifungal cream for candidiasis of the skin[cite: 5].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for an adult with a perianal abscess?
Comment: The guideline states that incision and drainage is the recommended management for a perianal abscess[cite: 2].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for an adult with constipation?
Comment: The guideline recommends bulk-forming laxatives for constipation in adults[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a child with chronic constipation?
Comment: The guideline recommends lactulose for a child with chronic constipation[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected anal fissure?
Comment: The guideline recommends bulk-forming laxatives for a patient with a suspected anal fissure[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for an adult with acute uncomplicated diarrhoea?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral rehydration solution for acute uncomplicated diarrhoea[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a child with acute diarrhoea?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral rehydration solution for a child with acute diarrhoea[cite: 2].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for a patient with dysentery?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral azithromycin for dysentery[cite: 2].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with uncomplicated tinea pedis (athlete's foot)?
Comment: The guideline recommends a topical antifungal cream for uncomplicated tinea pedis[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with tinea capitis (scalp ringworm)?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral griseofulvin for tinea capitis[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a chronic lower leg ulcer?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral cefalexin for a chronic lower leg ulcer[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a boil?
Comment: The guideline states that the recommended management for a boil is incision and drainage[cite: 5].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for an adult with a sore throat?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral analgesics for a sore throat[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected DVT[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a nosebleed?
A: Pinching the nostrils and leaning forward
B: Pinching the nostrils and leaning backward
Comment: The guideline states that the recommended management for a nosebleed is to pinch the nostrils and lean forward[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected fracture?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected fracture[cite: 19].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for a patient with a sprained ankle?
Comment: The guideline recommends Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation (RICE) for a sprained ankle[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a foreign body in the eye?
B: Removal of the foreign body with a cotton swab
Comment: The guideline recommends referral to an ophthalmologist for a foreign body in the eye[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected retinal detachment?
Comment: The guideline states that a patient with a suspected retinal detachment should be referred to an ophthalmologist immediately[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with acute otitis media?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral analgesics for the management of acute otitis media[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with chronic otitis media?
Comment: The guideline recommends referral to a specialist for a patient with chronic otitis media[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected mastoiditis?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected mastoiditis[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with suspected appendicitis?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for surgery for a patient with suspected appendicitis[cite: 2].

Questions: Which is a recommended treatment for a patient with oral candidiasis?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral nystatin for the treatment of oral candidiasis[cite: 1].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a dental abscess?
Comment: The guideline recommends referral to a dentist for a dental abscess[cite: 1].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a suspected cellulitis?
Comment: The guideline recommends oral antibiotics for the treatment of a suspected cellulitis[cite: 5].

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended management step for a patient with impetigo?
Comment: The guideline recommends a topical antibiotic for the treatment of impetigo[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with tinea corporis?
Comment: The guideline recommends a topical antifungal for the treatment of tinea corporis[cite: 5].

Questions: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for a patient with a boil?
Comment: The guideline states that the recommended management for a boil is incision and drainage[cite: 5].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a minor burn?
Comment: The guideline recommends cooling a minor burn with water[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a major burn?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a major burn[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected chemical burn?
A: Neutralizing the chemical with an alkali
B: Neutralizing the chemical with an acid
Comment: The guideline recommends irrigation with water for a chemical burn[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with an electrical burn?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with an electrical burn[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected stroke?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected stroke[cite: 15].

Questions: Which of the following is the correct management for a patient with chronic psychosis?
Comment: The guideline recommends long-term oral antipsychotic medication for chronic psychosis[cite: 16].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a suspected overdose of a benzodiazepine?
Comment: The guideline recommends flumazenil for a benzodiazepine overdose[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a foreign body in the ear?
Comment: The guideline recommends referral to a specialist for a foreign body in the ear[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a foreign body in the nose?
Comment: The guideline recommends referral to a specialist for a foreign body in the nose[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected head injury?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected head injury[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected spinal injury?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected spinal injury[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected hip fracture?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected hip fracture[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected femoral neck fracture?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected femoral neck fracture[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected humeral shaft fracture?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected humeral shaft fracture[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected radius fracture?
Comment: The guideline recommends immobilization and referral for a patient with a suspected radius fracture[cite: 19].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected carpal tunnel syndrome?
Comment: The guideline recommends splinting for carpal tunnel syndrome[cite: 20].

Questions: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected DVT[cite: 20].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism[cite: 20].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute myocardial infarction (AMI)?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected AMI[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected unstable angina?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected unstable angina[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute cardiac failure?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected acute cardiac failure[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute pulmonary oedema?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected acute pulmonary oedema[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute hypertensive crisis?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected acute hypertensive crisis[cite: 4].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute stroke?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected stroke[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected acute meningitis?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected acute meningitis[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected encephalitis?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected encephalitis[cite: 15].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected tetanus?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected tetanus[cite: 10].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected rabies?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected rabies[cite: 10].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected snakebite?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected snakebite[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected spider bite?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected spider bite[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected scorpion sting?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected scorpion sting[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected drug overdose?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for a patient with a suspected drug overdose[cite: 21].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a patient with a suspected suicidal attempt?
Comment: The guideline recommends immediate referral for psychiatric evaluation for a patient with a suspected suicidal attempt[cite: 16].

Questions: Which of the following is a key principle of respectful maternity care?
A: Always conduct examinations in public for transparency
B: Ensure informed consent and maintain confidentiality
C: Do not allow birth companions in labour wards
D: Share patient details with non-medical staff for safety
Comment: Respectful maternity care requires informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality to uphold women's dignity.

Questions: According to the guidelines what proportion of women in South Africa experience intimate partner violence during or after pregnancy?
Comment: This is the figure quoted in the guideline

Questions: What is the first-line pharmacological treatment for moderate to severe perinatal depression or anxiety?
Comment: SSRIs are safe and effective as first-line treatment during pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Questions: How is primary postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) defined?
B: Excessive bleeding from the genital tract within 24 hours
C: Blood loss greater than 1000ml within 48 hours
D: Blood loss greater than 2500ml at any point post-delivery
Comment: Primary PPH is defined as excessive bleeding within 24 hours after delivery.

Questions: Which of the following is a recognised risk factor for maternal mental health conditions?
Comment: Being a refugee or asylum seeker is a recognised risk factor.

Questions: What is the purpose of the BANC Plus antenatal schedule?
A: To reduce number of antenatal visits
B: To increase visits for improved monitoring
Comment: BANC Plus increased the number of visits to improve outcomes.

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a type of disrespect and abuse in maternity care?
A: Failure to provide services due to prejudice
B: Denying mobility or food in labour
Comment: Encouraging chosen birth positions is part of respectful care.

Questions: Which simple measure can improve respectful communication during labour?
D: Allowing only one examination per labour
Comment: Calling women by their preferred name improves rapport and respect.

Questions: Which statement about adolescent pregnancy is correct?
A: It carries lower risk than adult pregnancy
B: It is associated with higher risk of eclampsia and infections
D: It results in better neonatal outcomes
Comment: Adolescents face higher risks of complications such as eclampsia and infection.

Questions: Which of the following should be done when a woman is experiencing pregnancy loss?
B: Explain causes if known using simple language
C: Deny her access to the baby
Comment: Women should receive explanations and compassionate support during loss.

Questions: Which test is routinely used to screen for syphilis in pregnancy?
Comment: RPR is the standard screening test for syphilis in pregnancy.

Questions: What is the recommended first-line uterotonic for prevention of postpartum haemorrhage?
Comment: Oxytocin is the drug of choice for prevention of PPH.

Questions: Which of the following defines pre-eclampsia with severe features?
C: BP É?ù140/90 after 20 weeks with no symptoms
D: Any rise in BP in first trimester
Comment: Severe features include high BP with organ dysfunction such as headache, visual changes, or elevated creatinine.

Questions: What is the management of a septic miscarriage?
B: Immediate uterine evacuation and IV antibiotics
Comment: Septic miscarriage requires immediate uterine evacuation and IV antibiotics.

Questions: Which fetal heart rate is considered normal during labour?
Comment: Normal fetal heart rate in labour is 110É??160 bpm.

Questions: What is the safest delivery method for a transverse lie at term?
Comment: Transverse lie usually requires caesarean section for safe delivery.

Questions: What is the most appropriate response if a client is aggressive during labour care?
B: Remain calm and acknowledge their emotions
Comment: Remaining calm and acknowledging emotion de-escalates situations.

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended food supplement during pregnancy in South Africa?
Comment: Folic acid and iron supplementation is standard in pregnancy.

Questions: Which statement about kangaroo care is correct?
A: It should be avoided in preterm babies
B: It is recommended after delivery for bonding and warmth
D: It is unsafe after caesarean delivery
Comment: Skin-to-skin contact improves bonding and thermoregulation.

Questions: What is the most important first step in managing antepartum haemorrhage?
Comment: Initial step is resuscitation and maternal stabilisation.

Questions: Which infection is specifically screened for at booking in antenatal care?
Comment: HIV and syphilis are part of routine antenatal screening.

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a feature of respectful workplace culture?
Comment: Public criticism undermines respect and morale.

Questions: What is the role of a birth companion during labour?
Comment: Birth companions provide non-clinical emotional and practical support.

Questions: What is the most common mental health condition affecting South African women during or after pregnancy?
Comment: About 1 in 3 women experience perinatal depression or anxiety.

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended screening schedule for maternal mental health?
B: Once at booking and ideally each trimester
C: Only if patient has prior psychiatric history
Comment: Screening at booking and each trimester if possible helps early detection.

Questions: Which of the following describes Baby Blues?
B: Temporary emotional changes resolving within 2 weeks
Comment: Baby blues are transient emotional changes usually resolving within 2 weeks.

Questions: What is the recommended first-line treatment for eclampsia?
Comment: Magnesium sulphate is the drug of choice for preventing and treating seizures in eclampsia.

Questions: Which sign is most suggestive of abruptio placentae rather than placenta praevia?
Comment: Abruptio placentae typically presents with painful bleeding and uterine tenderness.

Questions: What is the safest method of induction of labour in a woman with a previous caesarean section?
C: Mechanical methods such as Foley catheter
Comment: Mechanical induction methods are safer in women with prior uterine scar.

Questions: Which of the following is part of the active management of the third stage of labour?
Comment: Active management includes oxytocin administration to reduce risk of PPH.

Questions: What is the most appropriate management for shoulder dystocia?
Comment: First-line management includes McRoberts manoeuvre and suprapubic pressure.

Questions: Which of the following is a key danger sign in postpartum women?
Comment: Heavy vaginal bleeding is a key danger sign for PPH.

Questions: What is the management of a retained placenta after vaginal delivery?
Comment: Manual removal under anaesthesia is needed if placenta does not deliver.

Questions: Which antiretroviral regimen is most commonly recommended for pregnant women living with HIV in South Africa?
Comment: TLD is the current first line regimen

Questions: Which measure helps prevent neural tube defects?
Comment: Folic acid supplementation before and during pregnancy reduces neural tube defects.

Questions: Which of the following defines gestational diabetes?
Comment: Gestational diabetes is hyperglycaemia first recognised during pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following maternal conditions increases risk of pre-eclampsia?
Comment: Obesity and chronic hypertension are risk factors for pre-eclampsia.

Questions: What is the definition of preterm labour?
Comment: Preterm labour refers to labour occurring before 37 completed weeks.

Questions: Which statement about VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Caesarean) is correct?
A: It is contraindicated in all women
B: It is possible in selected women with one previous low transverse scar
C: It is safest after three caesareans
D: It should be avoided in rural hospitals
Comment: VBAC can be safely attempted in selected women with one prior low transverse caesarean.

Questions: What is the first step in neonatal resuscitation?
B: Check breathing and stimulate the baby
Comment: Initial neonatal resuscitation begins with checking breathing and stimulation.

Questions: Which of the following contraceptive methods is safe in breastfeeding women from 6 weeks postpartum?
Comment: Progestogen-only methods are safe for breastfeeding mothers from 6 weeks.

Questions: Which infection in pregnancy requires intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis?
Comment: Intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis is used for Group B Streptococcus.

Questions: Which fetal presentation usually requires caesarean delivery?
Comment: Transverse lie usually requires caesarean delivery.

Questions: Which measure reduces mother-to-child transmission of HIV at delivery?
Comment: Exclusive breastfeeding with ART significantly reduces HIV transmission.

Questions: What is the management of mild anaemia in pregnancy?
Comment: Mild anaemia is managed with oral iron and folate supplementation.

Questions: Which of the following increases risk of postpartum depression?
Comment: Past psychiatric history increases risk of postpartum depression.

Questions: Which hypertensive disorder is defined as new hypertension after 20 weeks without proteinuria?
Comment: Gestational hypertension is diagnosed after 20 weeks without proteinuria.

Questions: Which of the following is the most effective emergency management of postpartum haemorrhage?
B: Immediate uterotonic drugs and uterine massage
Comment: Immediate use of uterotonic drugs and massage is essential.

Questions: What is the first-line management of epilepsy in pregnancy?
Comment: Lamotrigine or valproate are commonly used but valproate should be avoided if possible.

Questions: Which maternal infection requires screening and treatment to prevent congenital anomalies?
Comment: Syphilis screening and treatment prevents congenital anomalies and stillbirth.

Questions: Which of the following defines secondary postpartum haemorrhage?
B: Bleeding after 24 hours up to 12 weeks postpartum
Comment: Secondary PPH occurs after 24 hours up to 12 weeks postpartum.

Questions: Which of the following is the leading cause of maternal death in South Africa?
Comment: HIV-related conditions remain the leading cause of maternal mortality in South Africa.

Questions: What is the most appropriate management of severe pre-eclampsia at 32 weeks?
Comment: Definitive treatment of severe pre-eclampsia is delivery after maternal stabilisation.

Questions: What is the definition of puerperal sepsis?
A: Infection of the genital tract from miscarriage only
B: Infection of the genital tract from onset of rupture of membranes to 42 days postpartum
Comment: Puerperal sepsis is infection of the genital tract from rupture of membranes to 42 days postpartum.

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended intervention for small-for-gestational-age babies?
Comment: Management of SGA babies involves close surveillance and Doppler monitoring.

Questions: Which statement about breastfeeding in HIV-positive mothers is correct?
B: Exclusive breastfeeding with ART is recommended
C: Formula feeding is safer in all cases
Comment: Exclusive breastfeeding with ART is recommended to reduce HIV transmission.

Questions: Which of the following defines placenta praevia?
A: Placenta implanted in lower uterine segment covering cervix
B: Premature separation of normally implanted placenta
Comment: Placenta praevia refers to placental tissue covering or near the cervical os.

Questions: What is the most appropriate management of ectopic pregnancy in an unstable patient?
Comment: Unstable ruptured ectopic pregnancy requires immediate laparotomy with resuscitation.

Questions: Which vaccine is routinely recommended during pregnancy in South Africa?
Comment: Influenza and Tdap vaccines are recommended in pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following defines threatened miscarriage?
Comment: Threatened miscarriage is vaginal bleeding with a closed cervix.

Questions: Which of the following best describes respectful postnatal care?
Comment: Respectful postnatal care includes encouraging skin-to-skin contact.

Questions: Which is the most common cause of secondary postpartum haemorrhage?
Comment: Secondary PPH is most often due to retained tissue or infection.

Questions: What is the appropriate management of a woman with placenta praevia presenting with bleeding at 36 weeks?
Comment: Placenta praevia usually requires caesarean delivery at term.

Questions: Which of the following is a complication of multiple pregnancy?
B: Increased risk of fetal growth restriction
Comment: Multiple pregnancies carry higher risk of preterm labour and growth restriction.

Questions: Which of the following defines complete miscarriage?
Comment: In complete miscarriage, all products of conception are expelled.

Questions: What is the initial management of uterine inversion?
Comment: Immediate manual replacement of uterus is the first step.

Questions: Which of the following is a recommended method of induction of labour with favourable cervix?
Comment: Oxytocin is used when cervix is favourable.

Questions: What is the most common cause of perinatal mortality in South Africa?
Comment: Preterm birth complications are a leading cause of perinatal mortality.

Questions: Which of the following is NOT part of active management of PPH?
Comment: IV antibiotics are not part of active PPH management; they are used if infection is suspected.

Questions: Which of the following defines inevitable miscarriage?
B: Bleeding with open cervix and products visible
Comment: Inevitable miscarriage is bleeding with open cervix and visible products.

Questions: What is the most appropriate management of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy?
Comment: Asymptomatic bacteriuria requires oral antibiotics to prevent pyelonephritis.

Questions: Which antihypertensive is safe for use in pregnancy?
Comment: Methyldopa is a first-line antihypertensive safe in pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following is a feature of severe pre-eclampsia?
Comment: Severe pre-eclampsia involves high BP with organ dysfunction such as visual symptoms.

Questions: Which of the following is the most common site for ectopic pregnancy?
Comment: Most ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube.

Questions: Which intervention is recommended in cases of chorioamnionitis?
Comment: Chorioamnionitis requires IV antibiotics and delivery.

Questions: What is the most important step in preventing maternal deaths?
C: Implementing evidence-based guidelines at all levels
Comment: Maternal deaths can be reduced by applying national evidence-based guidelines widely.

Questions: Which of the following is a key principle of respectful care when engaging with adolescents?
Comment: Adolescents need non-judgmental, supportive care to encourage ANC attendance and improve outcomes.

Questions: What is the most appropriate management for malaria in pregnancy?
Comment: Artemisinin-based therapies are recommended for malaria in pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following is an indication for intrapartum CTG monitoring?
C: Preterm labour or suspected fetal compromise
Comment: CTG is indicated in high-risk cases such as preterm labour or suspected compromise.

Questions: Which mental health condition is most likely to present with hallucinations postpartum?
Comment: Postnatal psychosis can present with hallucinations and requires urgent care.

Questions: Which is the most common cause of maternal anaemia in South Africa?
Comment: Iron deficiency is the leading cause of maternal anaemia.

Questions: Which of the following is a danger sign in pregnancy requiring immediate referral?
Comment: Severe headache and blurred vision may indicate pre-eclampsia.

Questions: Which contraceptive method can be safely initiated immediately postpartum?
Comment: Progestogen-only methods can be safely initiated immediately postpartum.

Questions: Which of the following defines postpartum sepsis?
B: Genital tract infection within 42 days after birth
Comment: Postpartum sepsis refers to genital tract infection within 42 days postpartum.

Questions: Which is the most appropriate management of severe postpartum haemorrhage unresponsive to uterotonics?
C: Uterine balloon tamponade or surgical intervention
Comment: When uterotonics fail, balloon tamponade or surgery may be required.

Questions: Which of the following is the most important prevention strategy for obstetric fistula?
Comment: Preventing prolonged obstructed labour is key to preventing obstetric fistula.

Questions: Which of the following describes Tocophobia?
Comment: Tocophobia is an abnormal, persistent fear of childbirth.

Questions: Which condition is most strongly associated with neonatal death?
Comment: Preterm birth is strongly associated with neonatal mortality.

Questions: What is the first-line antibiotic for urinary tract infection in pregnancy?
Comment: Amoxicillin or cephalexin are safe first-line antibiotics in pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following defines recurrent miscarriage?
Comment: Recurrent miscarriage is defined as three or more consecutive losses.

Questions: Which of the following is recommended for mothers experiencing Baby Blues?
Comment: Baby Blues usually resolve with support; careful monitoring is important.

Questions: Which antiretroviral drug should be avoided in the first trimester due to risk of neural tube defects?
Comment: Dolutegravir is avoided in the first trimester due to neural tube defect risk.

Questions: What is the recommended management of prolonged pregnancy (>41 weeks)?
Comment: Induction of labour is recommended for prolonged pregnancy.

Questions: Which of the following is the safest analgesia for asthma in pregnancy?
Comment: Paracetamol is safe for pain relief in asthmatic pregnant women.

Questions: Which infection requires IPTp (intermittent preventive treatment) in pregnancy?
Comment: Malaria prevention during pregnancy includes intermittent preventive treatment in endemic areas.

Questions: Which of the following is a contraindication to induction of labour at district hospital level?
Comment: Previous caesarean section is a contraindication to IOL at district level.

Questions: Which of the following is part of respectful care when communicating across language barriers?
D: Only treating if interpreter is available
Comment: Simple communication, translation, and visual aids improve respectful care.

Questions: What is the first-line management for an HIV-exposed infant after birth?
Comment: HIV-exposed infants should receive nevirapine prophylaxis.

Questions: Which of the following is the most effective immediate management of eclampsia?
Comment: Magnesium sulphate is the immediate management for eclampsia seizures.

Questions: What is the recommended first-line management of gestational diabetes?
Comment: Diet and lifestyle are first-line; insulin is added if inadequate.

Questions: Which of the following defines complete placenta praevia?
A: Placenta implanted low but not covering cervix
Comment: Complete placenta praevia means placenta fully covers the cervical os.

Questions: What percentage of the estimated 27000 children with TB in South Africa were notified and reported to the WHO in 2022?
Comment: In 2022,  South Africa reported 16534 child TB notifications which accounts for 61% of the estimated 27000 children with TB in the country[cite: 30].

Questions: According to the guideline which of the following is a key update in the revised South African recommendations?
A: The use of a clinical treatment decision algorithm to support clinicians at the tertiary level.
B: The use of additional specimens to confirm a diagnosis of TB in children.
C: A new focus on treatment lengthening for non-severe forms of TB.
D: The exclusive use of the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) for diagnosis.
Comment: The new South African recommendations include key updates such as the use of additional specimens for diagnosis and a clinical treatment decision algorithm for primary health care clinicians[cite: 6, 7]

Questions: Which term has replaced 'latent TB' in the updated guidelines for children and adolescents?
Comment: The term latent TB has been replaced by the term TB infection as children are mostly recently infected

Questions: What is the definition of 'Significant TB Exposure' according to the guideline?
A: Exposure for at least 1 night or frequent daytime periods to a TB source patient within the last 3 months.
B: Exposure within 12 months to a TB source patient who started treatment >3 months ago.
C: Any exposure to a TB source patient within the last 6 months.
D: Exposure within 12 months to a TB source patient in the same enclosed space for É?ù 1 night or frequent daytime periods during the three months before the source patient started TB treatment.
Comment: Significant TB Exposure is defined as "Exposure within the 12 months before the child/adolescent presents with presumed TB to a person (adult or adolescent) with pulmonary TB within the same enclosed space for É?ù 1 night... or for frequent or extended daytime periods... during the three months before the source/index patient started TB treatment"[cite: 46].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT one of the "puzzle pieces" used to construct a TB diagnosis in children and adolescents?
Comment: The 'puzzle pieces' include patient history, clinical examination, HIV status, CXR, and diagnostic testing[cite: 481]

Questions: A child is considered to have 'presumptive TB' when:?
A: The diagnosis of TB is bacteriologically confirmed.
B: TB is considered a possible cause of illness based on symptoms or signs.
C: The child has a positive TST result.
D: The child has a history of significant TB exposure.
Comment: A child or adolescent is believed to have presumptive TB when TB is considered a possible cause of illness in those who present with symptoms or signs suggestive of TB[cite: 51].

Questions: What is the most common form of TB in children in high TB incidence countries like South Africa?
Comment: Pulmonary TB (PT is the most common form of TB in children[cite: 428].

Questions: Which of the following is a reason why TB in children is more difficult to diagnose bacteriologically compared to adults?
A: Children typically have a higher bacillary load.
B: Specimen collection is easier in children.
C: Children have paucibacillary disease with fewer bacilli.
D: The radiological picture is the same as in adults.
Comment: Younger children tend to have few detectable bacilli in their sputum/other respiratory specimens (paucibacillary disease) which makes detecting and confirming TB bacteriologically more difficult[cite: 429].

Questions: According to the guideline the BCG vaccine is especially protective against which forms of TB?
D: Severe forms of TB in infants and young children
Comment: The BCG vaccine is not fully protective against TB disease but is especially protective against severe forms of TB in infants and young children[cite: 434].

Questions: What is the recommended intensive phase duration for the treatment of drug-susceptible TB in children?
Comment: The treatment consists of an intensive phase of 2 months[cite: 135].

Questions: What is the recommended continuation phase duration for the treatment of non-severe PTB and/or cervical TB lymphadenitis if the child meets the eligibility criteria for treatment shortening?
Comment: In the patient with non-severe PTB and/or cervical TB lymphadenitis the continuation phase is two months provided the child meets the eligibility criteria for treatment shortening[cite: 137].

Questions: What is the typical duration of the continuation phase for children with bone and joint TB?
Comment: In children with bone and joint TB the duration of the continuation phase is typically prolonged up to 10 months or even longer in specific circumstances[cite: 139].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a component of the comprehensive package of care for TB?
D: Prescribing antibiotics for all concurrent illnesses.
Comment: The components of a comprehensive package of care for TB include providing anti-TB treatment identifying adult TB source patients preventing and managing co-morbid illnesses and providing psychosocial support[cite: 82 83].

Questions: What is the main reason for patients discontinuing medications as stated in the guideline?
B: Inadequate management of side effects and adverse events
Comment: Inadequate management of side effects and adverse events is the main reason patients discontinue medications and one of the primary reasons for treatment failure

Questions: Which of the following drugs is NOT listed as a potential cause of hepatotoxicity in children?
Comment: The most important adverse event on first-line medication is hepatotoxicity which can be caused by isoniazid rifampicin or pyrazinamide and very rarely by ethambutol[cite: 273]. which can be caused by isoniazid rifampicin or pyrazinamide and very rarely by ethambutol[cite: 273].

Questions: When should bacteriological monitoring be re-evaluated for a child on TB treatment?
B: If there is clinical deterioration or new exposure to a DR-TB source patient.
C: Only at the end of treatment.
D: Never, as it is rarely implemented in children
Comment: Re-evaluating the bacteriological status of a child becomes a priority if there is clinical deterioration or if there is a new exposure to a source patient with DR-TB[cite: 270].

Questions: For a child on a four or six-month regimen what is the management for a cumulative treatment interruption of less than one month?
A: Start the regimen over from the beginning.
B: Add additional doses to the end of the relevant treatment phase.
Comment: For a cumulative interruption of less than 1 month add additional doses to the end of the relevant treatment phase[cite: 289].

Questions: Which of the following statements about TB in children is correct?
A: They typically have a higher bacillary load than adults.
B: They usually develop TB within 24 months of exposure.
C: They may have a broad differential diagnosis for their symptoms.
D: They do not require a Chest X-ray for diagnosis.
Comment: Symptoms in children may be vague and may have a broad differential diagnosis[cite: 438].

Questions: What is the Ghon complex?
A: The combination of a parenchymal focus in the lung and the nearest mediastinal lymph node.
B: The initial site of mycobacterial multiplication in the lung.
C: The spread of TB bacilli via the lymphatic system.
Comment: The Ghon complex is formed by the parenchymal focus in the lung and the nearest mediastinal lymph node[cite: 447].

Questions: What are the risk factors for developing severe TB disease after exposure/infection in children?
A: Older age and being HIV negative.
B: Younger age, living with HIV, and/or having severe malnutrition
D: Being an adolescent with adult-type TB.
Comment: Being of younger age living with HIV or HIV exposure and/or having severe malnutrition are all risk factors for developing TB disease after TB exposure/infection[cite: 432]. living with HIV or HIV exposure and/or having severe malnutrition are all risk factors for developing TB disease after TB exposure/infection[cite: 432].

Questions: Which of the following is a key update in the revised South African guidelines mentioned in the foreword?
A: A focus on increasing the number of TB notifications in adults.
B: Practical guidance on treatment shortening for non-severe forms of TB in children and adolescents.
C: The use of a new anti-TB drug not yet approved by the WHO.
D: Exclusive reliance on bacteriological confirmation for diagnosis.
Comment: One of the key updates is "practical guidance on implementation of treatment shortening for non-severe forms of TB in children and adolescents"[cite: 6 7].

Questions: What is the recommended management for a child who deteriorates on TB treatment or has treatment failure?
A: Continue the current regimen for a longer duration.
B: Refer the child to the next level of care for further assessment and management.
D: Switch to a different anti-TB regimen without further investigation.
Comment: Any child with persistent symptoms or who deteriorates on TB treatment should be referred to the next level of care for further assessment and management[cite: 285].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a routine monitoring test for children and adolescents on ART as per the guideline?
Comment: Table 14 lists routine monitoring tests for children on ART as weight/height CD4 count VL creatinine FBC and electrolytes. Liver function tests are listed under a different heading (DILI)[cite: 13

Questions: What is the minimum level of integration primary care facilities should provide for a mother-child pair on the same day?
A: Level 1: Integrated care in one consulting room.
B: Level 2: Aligning visit schedules to attend the same facility on the same day.
C: Level 3: All needed care in the same room by the same provider.
D: No integration is necessary,  as long as care is provided.
Comment: Primary care facilities should at a minimum provide Level 1 integration[cite: 258].

Questions: Which of the following statements about adolescents with TB is true?
B: Bacteriological confirmation is less likely than in younger children.
C: Their presentation and diagnostic approach are similar to adults.
D: They are not at risk for extrapulmonary TB.
Comment: The presentation of and approach to diagnosing PTB in adolescents (10-19 years) is similar to that for adults[cite: 435].

Questions: Which two drug classes have significant drug interactions with rifampicin that reduce their blood concentrations?
D: Antiretroviral drugs and oral hypoglycaemic agents
Comment: Rifampicin has significant drug interactions with antiretroviral drugs that reduce ART concentrations in the blood and adolescents should be provided with contraception as appropriate due to these drug interactions[cite: 102 118].

Questions: According to the guidelines when should a decision to start TB treatment NOT be delayed?
A: When a TST is positive,  but other tests are pending.
B: When a TST is positive,  but other tests are pending.
C: When the child is over 10 years of age and clinically stable.
D: When a social worker has not yet completed the home visit.
Comment: A decision to start TB treatment should not be delayed if the necessary investigations are not available, particularly in children at higher risk of developing severe disease, such as young children, malnourished children or those living with HIV[cite: 75].A decision to start TB treatment should not be delayed if the necessary investigations are not available, particularly in children at higher risk of developing severe disease, such as young children, malnourished children or those living with HIV[cite: 75].

Questions: What is a key difference between TB in children and adults?
A: Children have a higher risk of poor outcomes if treated early.
B: The pathophysiology and clinical picture are identical.
C: Children have very good outcomes if started on appropriate treatment timeously.
D: Specimen collection is easier in children.
Comment: Children have very good outcomes if started on appropriate treatment timeously but the highest risk of poor outcomes if not treated[cite: 439].

Questions: In the pathophysiology of TB what is the term for the initial parenchymal focus in the lung?
B: The primary focus or Ghon focus
Comment: The initial parenchymal focus in the lung is called the primary focus or Ghon focus[cite: 446].

Questions: Which of the following is a symptom of Pulmonary TB (PT listed in the document?
Comment: Table 2 lists persistent cough (>2 weeks) as a symptom of Pulmonary TB[cite: 3].

Questions: According to the guideline what is the recommended management of a child with miliary tuberculosis?
A: Treatment is not delayed,  and the drug regimen is the same as for TBM.
B: Treatment is delayed until bacteriological confirmation is obtained.
C: The drug regimen is the same as for non-severe PTB.
Comment: Treatment should not be delayed while waiting for results; the anti-tuberculosis drug regimen is the same as for TBM[cite: 174].

Questions: What is the recommended approach to breastfeeding for a mother being treated for TB?
C: Breastfeeding should be encouraged for all mothers still able to breastfeed.
D: Breastfeeding is only recommended for mothers with non-severe TB.
Comment: Breastfeeding should be encouraged for all mothers still able to breastfeed[cite: 117].

Questions: What is the definition of a 'clinical diagnosis of TB'?
A: A diagnosis confirmed by a positive culture result.
B: A diagnosis based on history,  clinical findings,  and/or radiological features.
C: A diagnosis made when all bacteriological tests are positive.
D: A diagnosis made only in the absence of radiological features.
Comment: A diagnosis made on the grounds of history, clinical findings, radiological features, exposure history, growth trend, or a combination of the above, and where bacteriological tests were either not performed or the results were negative[cite: 52].

Questions: When should a child with a known TB exposure be considered for TB preventive treatment (TPT)?
A: When they have no symptoms and no radiological changes on CXR.
B: Only if they are also living with HIV.
D: as TPT is not part of the guideline.
Comment: Children with no symptoms and no radiological changes on CXR are classified as having TB infection (previously termed É??latentÉ?? T and should be considered for TB preventive treatment (TPT)[cite: 449 450].

Questions: In the context of the TB/HIV co-infected patient the guideline states that TB cannot be treated without also treating HIV. What is the reciprocal statement?
A: HIV can be treated without also treating TB.
B: HIV cannot be treated without also treating TB.
C: ART must be stopped during TB treatment.
D: TB treatment must be delayed until ART is started.
Comment: The guideline explicitly states: "In a TB/HIV co-infected patient TB cannot be treated without also treating HIV and HIV cannot be treated without also treating TB!"[cite: 104].

Questions: Which of the following is a danger sign in a child with TB needing urgent attention?
Comment: Box 1 lists convulsions as a danger sign needing urgent attention[cite: 11].

Questions: What is the recommended medication for supplemental pyridoxine?
Comment: Section 9.2 is titled "Supplemental pyridoxine" and lists the drug name[cite: 43].

Questions: According to the guideline which of the following is NOT a reason for the link between TB and malnutrition?
A: Malnutrition reduces cell-mediated immunity,  increasing the risk of TB disease.
B: The catabolic effect of TB disease results in weight loss.
C: Malnutrition makes TB treatment drugs less effective.
Comment: Box 5 lists malnutrition's effect on immunity and the catabolic effect of TB disease as reasons for the link between TB and malnutrition[cite: 119].

Questions: When should the BCG vaccine be repeated in an infant who initiated TPT or TB treatment in the first 6 weeks of life?
A: After completion of TPT or TB treatment
B: Never,  as it is a one-time vaccine.
C: Before TPT or TB treatment is started.
D: At 6 months of age,  regardless of treatment completion.
Comment: BCG should be repeated after completion of TPT or TB treatment[cite: 219].

Questions: What is the recommended TB drug regimen for a child under three months of age weighing less than 3 kg given the challenges with ethambutol administration?
D: The regimen should be delayed until the child is older.
Comment: ...ethionamide can be considered in infants younger than three months or weighing < 3kg, given the challenges with ethambutol administration and monitoring for ocular toxicity in the very young[cite: 135].

Questions: In children with presumed or confirmed DS-TBM what is the recommended management for hyponatremia?
Comment: Table 10 recommends restricting fluids for hyponatremia due to SIADH[cite: 16].

Questions: What is the recommended approach to Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) in the diagnostic process?
A: It is the first and only test needed.
B: It is only useful if there is no known TB exposure.
C: It is used to confirm bacteriological diagnosis.
D: It is a replacement for the chest X-ray.
Comment: The TST is only useful if no known TB exposure[cite: 62].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a routine TB programme activity that should be completed for monitoring and evaluation purposes?
Comment: Bacteriological monitoring is a part of patient monitoring but recording reporting identifying source patients and assessing post-TB health are listed as routine programme activities[cite: 83].

Questions: According to the guideline which of the following statements about drug adverse events in children is true?
A: They are more common in children than in adults.
B: Hepatotoxicity is rare,  occurring in less than 5% of children on first-line medication.
C: Hepatotoxicity is most likely to occur after 6 months of treatment.
Comment: Adverse events caused by TB medications are less common in children than in adults and "Hepatotoxicity... are rare (5% or lower) in children"[cite: 272 274]. 274].

Questions: The guideline suggests that for adolescents the approach to diagnosing PTB is similar to that of adults. What is a key reason for this similarity?
B: They are less likely to have EPTB.
D: They are not at risk for severe TB.
Comment: Bacteriological confirmation is more likely in adolescents who often have adult-type (cavitary) PTB disease[cite: 436].

Questions: Which of the following is a common Chest X-ray feature in perinatal TB?
Comment: Table 12 lists miliary infiltrates as a common Chest X-ray feature occurring in 30-40% of cases[cite: 190].

Questions: What is the recommended initial TB treatment regimen for a child with presumed or confirmed DS-TBM?
A: A 4-drug intensive phase for 2 months,  followed by a 2-drug continuation phase for 4 months.
B: A 4-drug intensive phase for 2 months,  followed by a 2-drug continuation phase for 7 months.
C: A 4-drug intensive phase for 2 months,  followed by a 2-drug continuation phase for 10 months.
D: The guideline defers to a specialist.
Comment: Table 9 on page 45 shows a 2 month intensive phase and a 10 month continuation phase[cite: 1718 19]. shows a 2 month intensive phase and a 10 month continuation phase[cite: 17

Questions: What is the main reason for the increased risk of disengagement and loss-to-follow-up (LTF) in TB management?
B: Failure to combine care into an integrated package.
Comment: Failure to combine care leads to increased visit schedules and significantly increases the risk of disengagement and loss-to-follow-up (LTF)[cite: 88].

Questions: When should a healthcare professional seek immediate care for a child on TB treatment?
A: If the child has a persistent cough.
B: If the child develops jaundice,  abdominal pain or vomiting.
C: If the child has a mild fever.
D: If the child has a loss of appetite.
Comment: The guideline instructs to seek immediate care if the child develops jaundice abdominal pain or vomiting[cite: 125].

Questions: What is the primary role of the Road to Health Booklet (RTH in TB management?
A: To serve as a legal document for TB treatment.
B: To provide a list of all TB drugs.
C: To document all relevant information regarding the child's TB diagnosis and treatment.
D: To replace the TB treatment register.
Comment: It is important to always take the RTHB along for any healthcare visits as it documents all relevant information regarding the child's TB diagnosis and treatment[cite: 128 129].

Questions: Which of the following is a consideration for TB treatment in co-infected children?
A: They are considered to have non-severe HIV disease.
B: They are at a lower risk of developing severe disease.
C: They are at the highest risk of death if not treated.
D: They can be treated without also treating HIV.
Comment: CALHIV and TB are at the highest risk of death if not treated[cite: 100].

Questions: Which of the following tests should NOT be used to monitor response to treatment?
Comment: NAAT testing should NOT be used to monitor response to treatment[cite: 269].

Questions: In the management of a newborn exposed to TB when should the infant be separated from the mother for infection control?
A: If the mother is known to be contagious.
B: For the first 24 hours after birth.
C: When the infant develops symptoms of TB.
D: Separation is not recommended,  even if the mother is still contagious.
Comment: It is not recommended that infants be separated from their mothers after birth even if the mother is known to still be contagious[cite: 200].

Questions: Which of the following is a definition of bacteriologically confirmed TB?
A: Diagnosis based on a positive TST and CXR.
B: Diagnosis confirmed by clinical findings and exposure history.
C: Diagnosis confirmed using genotypic testing (TB-NAAT),  mycobacterial culture,  and/or smear microscopy.
D: Diagnosis made in the absence of bacteriological tests.
Comment: Bacteriologically confirmed TB is when the diagnosis of TB disease is confirmed using genotypic testing (TB-NAAT) mycobacterial culture and/or smear microscopy for acid-fast bacilli (AF[cite: 53].

Questions: Which type of TB is defined as involving organs other than the lungs airways and intrathoracic lymph nodes?
Comment: Extrapulmonary TB is defined as "any bacteriologically confirmed or clinically diagnosed patient with TB involving organs other than the lungs airways and intrathoracic lymph nodes"[cite: 55].

Questions: In adolescents which type of TB disease is most likely to be bacteriologically confirmed?
Comment: Bacteriological confirmation is more likely in adolescents who often have adult-type (cavitary) PTB disease[cite: 436].

Questions: What is the typical duration of the intensive phase for all children and adolescents with DS-TB (excluding TBM other forms of CNS TB and miliary T?
Comment: All children and adolescents with DS-TB (excluding TBM other forms of CNS TB and miliary T will initiate the same intensive phase of TB treatment using four anti-TB medications. The duration is 2 months[cite: 136 137].

Questions: What is the recommended management of a child with Tuberculoma?
A: Anti-tuberculosis therapy is the same as for TBM.
C: A different regimen from TBM is used.
D: Treatment is only required if neurological symptoms are present.
Comment: Anti-tuberculosis therapy is the same as for TBM. Prednisone is also recommended[cite: 167 169].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a factor that influences the timing of ART initiation in a TB/HIV co-infected patient?
D: Adherence due to increased pill burden.
Comment: The timing of ART initiation is affected by antiretroviral drug selection drug interactions with rifampicin adherence due to increased pill burden and side effects due to overlapping toxicities[cite: 101102 103].

Questions: What is a key difference in TB management between children and adults as stated in the guideline?
A: Treatment is always the same for both age groups.
B: Children may have more rapid disease progression.
Comment: CALHIV may have more rapid TB disease progression and are at higher risk of developing severe disease[cite: 99].

Questions: What is the recommended drug regimen for the intensive phase of treatment for perinatal TB?
B: Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide,  and Ethambutol or Ethionamide
Comment: The intensive phase consists of four drugs: isoniazid rifampicin and pyrazinamide and a fourth drug: either ethambutol or ethionamide[cite: 191].

Questions: What is the purpose of the clinical treatment decision algorithm mentioned in the foreword?
B: To enable and support clinicians at the primary health care level to start TB treatment.
C: To be used only at the tertiary level of care.
D: To determine which patients are eligible for surgery.
Comment: The clinical treatment decision algorithm is intended "to enable and support clinicians at the primary health care level to start TB treatment"[cite: 7].

Questions: What is the reason given for replacing the term 'latent TB' with 'TB infection' in children?
C: 'TB infection' is a more accurate term for all age groups.
D: The term 'latent' is only used for adults.
Comment: The term É??latent TBÉ?ù has been replaced by the term É??TB infectionÉ?ù as children are mostly recently infected[cite: 49].

Questions: What is the main purpose of the SHINE trial mentioned in Annexure 4?
A: To study drug-resistant TB in adults.
B: To assess the efficacy of treatment shortening in children with non-severe TB.
C: To find a new drug for TB treatment.
D: To compare different diagnostic tests for TB.
Comment: SHINE was a multi-centre phase 3 open-label treatment-shortening non-inferiority trial in children with non-severe symptomatic smear-negative presumed drug-susceptible (DS)-TB[cite: 312].

Questions: Which of the following is a correct statement about a child with TB who is on ART?
A: ART is not needed if the child is already on TB treatment.
B: ART should be stopped during TB treatment.
C: The child should be on ART, clinically well, and have a CD4% > 25 to receive a BCG
D: The BCG vaccine can be given at any time regardless of CD4
Comment: If the infant is also LHIV they should be on ART clinically well and have a CD4 > 25% to be able to receive BCG[cite: 219]. clinically well

Questions: What is the recommended management of a child with spinal arachnoiditis identified on an MRI?
A: It should be managed as TBM.
B: It should be managed with anti-inflammatory drugs only.
C: No treatment is necessary unless there is bone disease.
D: The regimen should be the same as for non-severe PTB.
Comment: If this is identified on an MRI it should be managed as TBM[cite: 171].

Questions: According to the guideline what is the role of Chest X-rays in TB diagnosis?
A: It is the only puzzle piece needed for diagnosis.
B: It is a puzzle piece if available,  but not always required to start treatment.
C: It replaces the need for diagnostic testing.
D: It is only useful in adolescents.
Comment: The CXR is a puzzle piece used to construct a TB diagnosis if it is available[cite: 483 492]. A decision to start treatment should not be delayed if necessary investigations like a CXR are not available particularly in high-risk children[cite: 75].

Questions: What is the recommended waiting period after the last anti-TB treatment dose before an infant can receive the BCG vaccine?
Comment: BCG vaccination should be done 24 hours after the last anti-TB treatment dose[cite: 223].

Questions: What is the recommended use of corticosteroids in children with miliary tuberculosis?
B: They are recommended for all children with miliary tuberculosis.
C: They are only recommended if there are neurological features.
D: Their use is not mentioned in the guideline.
Comment: The use of prednisone in all children with miliary tuberculosis is recommended[cite: 176].

Questions: What are the components of the intensive phase of treatment for drug-susceptible PTB and EPTB (excluding TBM,  other forms of CNS TB and miliary T?
D: Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide,  and Ethambutol or Ethionamide
Comment: The intensive phase consists of 4 drugs: isoniazid rifampicin and pyrazinamide and a fourth drug which is either ethambutol or ethionamide[cite: 135].

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a reason for providing patient education to a child/adolescent and their family?
C: To increase the cost of treatment
Comment: The guideline states that patient education is aimed at an informed and empowered patient/caregiver who is less fearful and this results in better treatment outcomes[cite: 123].

Questions: What is the definition of Pulmonary Tuberculosis (PT?
A: TB involving only the lung tissue.
B: TB involving the lung tissue, airways or draining lymph nodes
C: TB involving only the intrathoracic lymph nodes.
D: TB involving organs other than the lungs.
Comment: Pulmonary tuberculosis (PT refers to TB involving the lung tissue airways or draining lymph nodes[cite: 54]. airways or draining lymph nodes[cite: 54].

Questions: What is the recommended duration of the continuation phase for a child with severe PTB and most EPTB?
Comment: For severe PTB and most EPTB the continuation phase duration is 4 months[cite: 142].

Questions: What is the purpose of U-LAM testing in children living with HIV (CLHIV)?
D: The guideline does not mention U-LAM.
Comment: U-LAM is listed under 'Special investigations' in Figure 2 in the box for assessing for TB infection or TB disease[cite: 62].

Questions: Which of the following is a definition of a drug-susceptible TB (DS-T?
A: M.tb strains that are resistant to first-line agents.
B: M.tb strains that are susceptible to first-line agents rifampicin and isoniazid.
C: Any patient with TB involving organs other than the lungs.
D: The form of TB that requires the longest treatment regimen.
Comment: Drug-susceptible TB (DS-T is defined as M.tb strains that are susceptible to the first-line agents rifampicin and isoniazid[cite: 56].
